Cool. It would be great to see Go-Explore on Castlevania!



Best regards,
=
Jeff Clune

Loy and Edith Harris Associate Professor in Computer Science
Di=
rector, Evolving Artificial Intelligence Lab <http://evolvingai.org/>
Unive=
rsity of Wyoming
jeffclune@... <mailto:jeffclune@...>
jeffclune.c=
om <http://jeffclune.com/>

Senior Research Manager (Staff Scientist), and =
Founding Member
Uber AI Labs <http://uber.ai/>




> On Feb 7, 2019, at 4:2=
0 PM, djames@... [neat] <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
> 
> 
> I haven=
't posted here in a long while, and I'm not in academia anymore, but I occa=
sionally continue experimenting with neural networks and evolutionary algor=
ithms. I recently launched a Twitch channel to stream/record some of my rec=
ent experiments, and I thought I'd share in case anyone was interested:
> 
=
> 
> 
> https://www.twitch.tv/derelictai <https://www.twitch.tv/derelictai>=

> 
> Currently I'm working on evolving morphologies and controllers for vi=
rtual creatures, akin to Karl Sims' work back in the 90s. Recently, I was a=
lso evolving neural networks to try to play classic NES games, such as Gala=
ga and Castlevania.
> 
> 
> 
> Lots of parameters and different avenues to =
explore. So far with the virtual creatures, I'm not getting a very large va=
riety of behaviors. "Rolling" tends to be the primary strategy for moving a=
long a solid substrate with the fitness function simply being max distance =
traveled. I need to fiddle with the mutation of new body parts and their al=
lowable locations relative to their parent, and also the joint parameters. =
I'm also playing around with different shapes for the rigid bodies. I'm usi=
ng jMonkeyEngine, which uses jBullet for the underlying physics, and it all=
ows for other rigid body shapes such as spheres, cones, capsules, etc.
> 
>=
 
> 
> Anyway, I'm willing to start a discussion if anyone else is or has a=
ctively worked in this area or is interested. Otherwise, I'll just keep plu=
gging away in my own little corner of the internet. 
> 
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_3226DDC3-A5C2-4BDF-BAE0-713AD5A11F37

in: 0px 0px 1em;" class=3D""><br class=3D"webkit-block-placeholder"></div><=
p style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; margin: 0px 0px 1em;" class=3D"">I haven't =
posted here in a long while, and I'm not in academia anymore, but I occasio=
nally continue experimenting with neural networks and evolutionary algorith=
ms. I recently launched a Twitch channel to stream/record some of my recent=
 experiments, and I thought I'd share in case anyone was interested:</p><p =
style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; margin: 0px 0px 1em;" class=3D""><br style=3D=
"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""></p><p style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; marg=
in: 0px 0px 1em;" class=3D""><a rel=3D"nofollow" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"=
https://www.twitch.tv/derelictai" style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; font-family=
: Verdana;" class=3D"">https://www.twitch.tv/derelictai</a><br style=3D"lin=
e-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""></p><p style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; margin: =
0px 0px 1em;" class=3D""><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""></p>=
<p style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; margin: 0px 0px 1em;" class=3D"">Currently=
 I'm working on evolving morphologies and controllers for virtual creatures=
, akin to Karl Sims' work back in the 90s. Recently, I was also evolving ne=
ural networks to try to play classic NES games, such as Galaga and Castleva=
nia.</p><p style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; margin: 0px 0px 1em;" class=3D""><=
br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""></p><p style=3D"line-height: 1=
.22em; margin: 0px 0px 1em;" class=3D"">Lots of parameters and different av=
enues to explore. So far with the virtual creatures, I'm not getting a very=
 large variety of behaviors. "Rolling" tends to be the primary strategy for=
 moving along a solid substrate with the fitness function simply being max =
distance traveled. I need to fiddle with the mutation of new body parts and=
 their allowable locations relative to their parent, and also the joint par=
ameters. I'm also playing around with different shapes for the rigid bodies=
. I'm using jMonkeyEngine, which uses jBullet for the underlying physics, a=
nd it allows for other rigid body shapes such as spheres, cones, capsules, =
etc.</p><p style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; margin: 0px 0px 1em;" class=3D""><=
br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""></p><p style=3D"line-height: 1=
.22em; margin: 0px 0px 1em;" class=3D"">Anyway, I'm willing to start a disc=
ussion if anyone else is or has actively worked in this area or is interest=
ed. Otherwise, I'll just keep plugging away in my own little corner of the =
internet. </p><div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; margin: 0px 0px 1em;"=
 class=3D""><br class=3D"webkit-block-placeholder"></div></div><div style=
